answer_html: Now, since \(\lim_{x \to 3} 2x-3 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}\) and\(\lim_{x \to 3} x^2-4x+6 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}\), we conclude by the squeeze theorem that \(\lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = {\color{blue}3}\).
answer_latex:
Now, since $\lim_{x \to 3} 2x-3 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}$ and$\lim_{x \to 3} x^2-4x+6 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}$, we conclude by the
squeeze theorem that $\lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = {\color{blue}3}$.
hints_html:
Try applying the squeeze theorem.

The squeeze theorem states that if \(g(x) \leq f(x) \leq h(x)\) for all \(\displaystyle x\) in some interval \(\displaystyle I\), and \(a \in I\), then:

\(\lim_{x \to a} g(x) = \lim_{x \to a} h(x) = L \implies \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L\)
hints_latex:
The squeeze theorem states that if $g(x) \leq f(x) \leq h(x)$ for all
$\displaystyle x$ in some interval $\displaystyle I$, and $a \in I$,
then:\\\\$\lim_{x \to a} g(x) = \lim_{x \to a} h(x) = L \implies \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L$
hints_raw:
Try applying the '''squeeze theorem'''.
The squeeze theorem states that if <math>g(x) \leq f(x) \leq h(x)</math> for all <math>\displaystyle x</math> in some interval <math>\displaystyle I</math>, and <math>a \in I</math>, then:<br><br>
<math> \lim_{x \to a} g(x) = \lim_{x \to a} h(x) = L \implies \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L</math>
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
Firstly, we are given that \(2x-3 \leq f(x) \leq x^2-4x+6\) for all \(x \in [-1, \infty)\). Since \(3 \in [-1, \infty)\), the initial condition of the squeeze theorem is satisfied.

Now, since \(\lim_{x \to 3} 2x-3 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}\) and\(\lim_{x \to 3} x^2-4x+6 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}\), we conclude by the squeeze theorem that \(\lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = {\color{blue}3}\).

$x \in [-1, \infty)$. Since $3 \in [-1, \infty)$, the initial condition
of the squeeze theorem is satisfied.

Now, since $\lim_{x \to 3} 2x-3 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}$ and$\lim_{x \to 3} x^2-4x+6 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}$, we conclude by the
squeeze theorem that $\lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = {\color{blue}3}$.
sols_raw:
Firstly, we are given that <math>2x-3 \leq f(x) \leq x^2-4x+6</math> for all <math>x \in [-1, \infty)</math>. Since <math>3 \in [-1, \infty)</math>, the initial condition of the squeeze theorem is satisfied.

Now, since <math>\lim_{x \to 3} 2x-3 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}</math> and <math>\lim_{x \to 3} x^2-4x+6 = {\color{OliveGreen} 3}</math>, we conclude by the squeeze theorem that <math>\lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = {\color{blue} 3}</math>.
